member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchProcess
member.summary: Represents a single batch process executing actions defined by batch handlers.

remarks.para: The action handled and executed by the class is provided and represented by an instance, implementation of the . The is also holding all the event handlers which should be involved during the main action execution.
The can be seen as a thread with an action to be run (handler).
The has a name and it is recommended to keep this name unique among all the processes defined and created within the application. The name allows us to identify the batch process when it is running.

When one of the or methods is called the method is executed. Execution happens on a new thread and by usage of the thread pool. When using shared resources the correct synchronization and memory barriers should be set.
The task, action can be in one of the states described by the . The current state of the process can be examined by usage of the property.
When the or the method is called the process will transition from the state into the . When the process is already running the call into the Run method will take no effects.
Only a process being in the state can be started via one of the Run methods.
The process is in the state by default (when created). It can also be created in the state when this is requested on the ctor parameters.

At any point in time a running process can be stopped. For that the method can be used. When a stop is requested the process may transition from the state into the state. When the process is already stopped or not started yet a request to stop it will be accepted immediately as not additional actions are needed.

When a requested stop has succeeded the batch process will change its state from the into the state. When a stop has been requested it will not be possible to run the action, process again and any calls into one of the Run methods will be ignored. It means the process in the state or in the state cannot be executed again by usage of Run methods.
The process can be reactivated by the method so it moves into the state. When this is done a process can be run. Only a fully stopped process being in the state can be reactivated.
The itself has no information about any time schedulers and has no notion of time. For scheduled batch processes please check the class.
In most of the scenarios the class is not used directly. The is used instead and a complete initialization of batch processes is based on the application configuration file.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.IBatchProcess.Reactivate
member.summary: Reactivates the already process so it can be run.

remarks.para: The Reactivate method is able to move the already process into the state so the process can be run.
When the process is already in the or state no reactivation is needed as the process is already active.
When the process is in the state no reactivation is possible as the process must be fully stopped in order to be reactivated.
Onces the process has been successfully reactivated it is possible to use one of the Run methods on it.

member.returns: True if the process has been reactivated, is active and in or state.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.IScheduledBatchProcess.ScheduleOrRun
member.summary: Runs the scheduled process or schedule it for execution in the future.

remarks.para: The method runs the process if its scheduled execution point is pointing at the past. It means the process should have already been started and an immediate execution of it is required. In that case no is returned by the method.

The method schedules the process to be run if its execution point is pointing in the future. It means the process should not run now be it should be scheduled for the future execution. In that case a future execution point is returned by the method (a waiting time to this point represented by the value).
The method examines processes in the state only. Only the Ready processes can be run. The rest of processes are ignores by the method.

returns.para: The future execution point at which the process should run. This point is represented by the waiting time (). The waiting time specifies how much the caller should wait before the process can run.
Null value when the process has been run or when the process cannot be run due to its incorrect state.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.IScheduledBatchProcess.ScheduleOrRun(System.Action)
member.summary: Runs the scheduled process or schedule it for execution in the future.

remarks.para: The method runs the process if its scheduled execution point is pointing at the past. It means the process should have already been started and an immediate execution of it is required. In that case no is returned by the method.

The method schedules the process to be run if its execution point is pointing in the future. It means the process should not run now be it should be scheduled for the future execution. In that case a future execution point is returned by the method (a waiting time to this point represented by the value).
The method examines processes in the state only. Only the Ready processes can be run. The rest of processes are ignores by the method.

returns.para: The future execution point at which the process should run. This point is represented by the waiting time (). The waiting time specifies how much the caller should wait before the process can run.
Null value when the process has been run or when the process cannot be run due to its incorrect state.
returns.param: The method called when the process has been run and its execution has completed.

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.ScheduledBatchProcess
member.summary: The class represents a scheduled batch process which contains information about a point in time at which the batch process action should run.

remarks.para: The uses the implementation of the in order to get the notion of time and in order to has knowledge about the expected execution points.
The is always representing a single point in time at which the execution should occur. This point is exposed by the .
It is the implementation of the which has the time scheduling logic. This logic is reused by the in the calculation of the execution points.

The is alway up to date when the state of the process is . For all other states the last set and used value (if any) is present as the execution point. It means it is the last point at which the execution has been started.

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Config.WinServiceConfigurationFactory
member.summary: Acts like a default configuration factory.

remarks.para: The implementations of the interfaces are used to move the configuration out of the service class itself. One may provide an implementation of the and pass it into one of the constructors.
The acts like a default configuration factory object. When the parameter less constructor is used this class will provide a configuration for the NVS Windows Service.

The will resolve the configuration in the following way:
When the has been configured in code using one of the common library configuration methods provided on the configuration interface then this configuration will be used. See the and the for details.
When no configuration has been provided by usage of the common, fluent library configuration methods the configuration according to the current application configuration file is expected. In this case the application configuration file must contain specific configuration sections and nodes. See the and the .
For more details and sample about the configuration check the class itself.

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchHandler
member.summary: The base and abstract batch handler implementation (an action to be run by a batch process). Typically an application creates from 1 - N batch handlers which are representing actions to be executed according to the predefined execution schedule.

remarks.para: An implementation of the represents a batch action to be executed together with all the event handlers which should also be used and involved during the execution.
The is a base implementation of the which can be used by all the handlers in your application. This class simplifies usage and provides basic error handling.

The provides a basic error handling by usage of the . The should be registered and mapped within the Unity in order to be used. Its registration is optional and when not provided the logging will be discarded.
When an error occurs during the execution of the method the method is called. The basic implementation logs a detected error.
Every implementation of the method should respect the cancellation token received. Long running actions should always check for cancellation, rollback and exit when such cancellation is set.

example.para: The following code creates a custom batch handler. All the errors are automatically logged.

remarks.para: Wherever you want to create the batch executing some action you need to implement the batch handler. For more details check the .

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.CronTimeScheduler
member.summary: The batch process time scheduler calculating execution points in time according to the given cron expressions.

remarks.para: Batch schedulers are used in order to specify points in time at which the batch processes should execute. Schedulers are commonly used by the class which instances are automatically managed by the . In most scenarios it is enough to only use the batch windows service managing batch processes where the complete configuration is based on the application configuration file and all the schedulers are created based on this configuration. In such a common scenario direct usage of scheduling classes is not needed.
The provides scheduling capabilities based on cron expressions.

Cron is a commonly used tool that has been around for a long time and it enables powerful scheduling capabilities. The class is based on the scheduling capabilities of cron and cron expressions are used in order to specify recursive execution points in time.

A cron expression is a string composed from 6 to 7 fields separated by white spaces. The following fields may occur in the single cron expression:
Field Values
Seconds 0-59
Minutes 0-59
Hours 0-23
Day of month 1-31
Month 1-12 or JAN-DEC
Day of week 1-7 or SUN-SAT
Year (optional) empty, 1970-2099

Special characters can be used in cron expressions:
* - all values
? - no specific value
- - specify range
, - specify additional values
/ - specify increments
L - last
W - weekday

Samples of cron expressions:
Expression Description
0 0 12 * * ? Fire at 12pm every day
0 15 10 ? * * Fire at 10:15am every day
0 15 10 * * ? 2005 Fire at 10:15am every day during the year 2005
0 0/5 14 * * ? Fire every 5 minutes starting at 2pm and ending at 2:55pm, every day

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.PeriodicTimeScheduler
member.summary: The base, abstract periodic time scheduler tracing last run time of a batch process and calculating the next execution point in time (for the next process).

remarks.para: The is a base class for the recurring time schedulers. A recurring time scheduler manages execution of processes in a continuous manner. Every time a process is ended a new execution point should be calculated and a process should run again.
The calculates the current point in time as the . It means the Utc should also be used for calculation of points performed by the .
For more information about scheduling see and .

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.ITimeScheduler
member.summary: Defines a contract which should be fulfilled by every batch process time scheduler.

remarks.para: A time scheduler specifies points in time at which a batch process should run. A scheduler calculates those points and has a notion of time. A batch process itself has no scheduling logic and for time based execution it always reuses one of the scheduler implementations.
Different types of time schedulers are possible for example: interval based, recursive, one time and more. When a time scheduler should be created a class derived from the must be added.
Check also one of the existing implementations for a sample: , .
For more information about scheduling see and .

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.ITimeScheduler.MarkStartingPoint
member.summary: Marks a point in time at which the scheduled process has been started.
member.remarks: A scheduler may trace points at which scheduled processes have been started. When a process starts a consumer may call this method so the scheduler is notified.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.ITimeScheduler.CalculateCurrent
member.summary: Calculates the point in time which represents the current date and time.
member.remarks: The current point in time is similar to the known DateTime.Now, DateTime.UtcNow but it is specific for the current scheduler. For example: it may not contain information about milliseconds if those should be removed for the current time calculations done by the current scheduler.
member.returns: The point in time representing the current date and time (now).

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.ITimeScheduler.CalculateNext
member.summary: Calculates the next point in time at which the batch process should run.
member.remarks: The scheduler calculates the next point assuming the current point in time is as returned bu the implementation of the .
member.returns: The point in time at which the next process is expected to run.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.PeriodicTimeScheduler.MarkStartingPoint
member.summary: Marks a point in time at which the scheduled process has been started.
member.remarks: The scheduler traces points at which scheduled processes have been started. When a process starts a consumer calls this method so the scheduler is notified.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.PeriodicTimeScheduler.CalculateCurrent
member.summary: Calculates the current point in time specific for the periodic time scheduler and basing on the UTC time offset.
member.returns: The current point in time used by the scheduler (Now).

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.PeriodicTimeScheduler.CalculateNext
member.summary: Calculates the next point in time at which the process is expected to run.
member.returns: The next point in time at which the process is expected to run.

member.name: P:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.PeriodicTimeScheduler.LastRun
member.summary: The point in time at which the process has been started for the least time.
member.remarks: The last run is set by the class consumer when a scheduled process is starting. The last run can be used to identify the total scheduler process running or waiting time. It can be null when nothing has been run yet.

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.IntervalTimeScheduler
member.summary: The batch process time scheduler running processes using the given time interval.

remarks.para: Batch schedulers are used in order to specify points in time at which the batch processes should execute. Schedulers are commonly used by the class which instances are automatically managed by the . In most scenarios it is enough to only use the batch windows service managing batch processes where the complete configuration is based on the application configuration file and all the schedulers are created based on this configuration. In such a common scenario direct usage of scheduling classes is not needed.

The time interval specifies the frequency at which the process is expected to run. The interval is a simple time information which is expected between each run of the process. The interval may for example schedule the following: run a process every 1 second.

The interval is calculated between last point in time at which the process has been started and the next, expected point in time at which the process should begin:
Distance between the Process Start(1) -> Process Start(2)

The given interval for the is the wanted interval and it is often not what is physically between the two process start points. It is the optimum which the scheduler wants to reach and be close as much as possible.
The runs the process immediately when it is scheduled.

Next time (the next process run) depends on the requested interval and the execution time of the previous process.
If execution time of the previous process is less than the requested interval than a scheduler calculates the next starting point willing to keep the interval between the processes as close as possible into the requested interval (the delay time for the next run is calculated).
When the execution time exceeded the requested interval the next process is run immediately when the previous one is completed. We have passed our requested interval so we must run the next action as fast as possible (no delays, we are over time).

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.Schedulers.CronExpression
member.summary: Provides a parser and evaluator for unix-like cron expressions. Cron expressions provide the ability to specify complex time combinations such as "At 8:00am every Monday through Friday" or "At 1:30am every last Friday of the month".

remarks.para: Cron expressions are comprised of 6 required fields and one optional field separated by white space. The fields respectively are described as follows:
The '*' character is used to specify all values. For example, "*" in the minute field means "every minute".

The '?' character is allowed for the day-of-month and day-of-week fields. It is used to specify 'no specific value'. This is useful when you need to specify something in one of the two fields, but not the other.
The '-' character is used to specify ranges For example "10-12" in the hour field means "the hours 10, 11 and 12".
The ',' character is used to specify additional values. For example "MON,WED,FRI" in the day-of-week field means "the days Monday, Wednesday, and Friday".

The '/' character is used to specify increments. For example "0/15" in the seconds field means "the seconds 0, 15, 30, and 45". And "5/15" in the seconds field means "the seconds 5, 20, 35, and 50". Specifying '*' before the '/' is equivalent to specifying 0 is the value to start with. Essentially, for each field in the expression, there is a set of numbers that can be turned on or off. For seconds and minutes, the numbers range from 0 to 59. For hours 0 to 23, for days of the month 0 to 31, and for months 1 to 12. The "/" character simply helps you turn on every "nth" value in the given set. Thus "7/6" in the month field only turns on month "7", it does NOT mean every 6th month, please note that subtlety.

The 'L' character is allowed for the day-of-month and day-of-week fields. This character is short-hand for "last", but it has different meaning in each of the two fields. For example, the value "L" in the day-of-month field means "the last day of the month" - day 31 for January, day 28 for February on non-leap years. If used in the day-of-week field by itself, it simply means "7" or "SAT". But if used in the day-of-week field after another value, it means "the last xxx day of the month" - for example "6L" means "the last friday of the month". You can also specify an offset from the last day of the month, such as "L-3" which would mean the third-to-last day of the calendar month. When using the 'L' option, it is important not to specify lists, or ranges of values, as you'll get confusing/unexpected results.

The 'W' character is allowed for the day-of-month field. This character is used to specify the weekday (Monday-Friday) nearest the given day. As an example, if you were to specify "15W" as the value for the day-of-month field, the meaning is: "the nearest weekday to the 15th of the month". So if the 15th is a Saturday, the trigger will fire on Friday the 14th. If the 15th is a Sunday, the trigger will fire on Monday the 16th. If the 15th is a Tuesday, then it will fire on Tuesday the 15th. However if you specify "1W" as the value for day-of-month, and the 1st is a Saturday, the trigger will fire on Monday the 3rd, as it will not 'jump' over the boundary of a month's days. The 'W' character can only be specified when the day-of-month is a single day, not a range or list of days.
The 'L' and 'W' characters can also be combined for the day-of-month expression to yield 'LW', which translates to "last weekday of the month".

The '#' character is allowed for the day-of-week field. This character is used to specify "the nth" XXX day of the month. For example, the value of "6#3" in the day-of-week field means the third Friday of the month (day 6 = Friday and "#3" = the 3rd one in the month). Other examples: "2#1" = the first Monday of the month and "4#5" = the fifth Wednesday of the month. Note that if you specify "#5" and there is not 5 of the given day-of-week in the month, then no firing will occur that month. If the '#' character is used, there can only be one expression in the day-of-week field ("3#1,6#3" is not valid, since there are two expressions).
The legal characters and the names of months and days of the week are not case sensitive.

ul.li: Support for specifying both a day-of-week and a day-of-month value is not complete (you'll need to use the '?' character in one of these fields).

Overflowing ranges is supported - that is, having a larger number on the left hand side than the right. You might do 22-2 to catch 10 o'clock at night until 2 o'clock in the morning, or you might have NOV-FEB. It is very important to note that overuse of overflowing ranges creates ranges that don't make sense and no effort has been made to determine which interpretation CronExpression chooses. An example would be "0 0 14-6 ? * FRI-MON".

member.author: Sharada Jambula
James House
Contributions from Mads Henderson
Refactoring from CronTrigger to CronExpression by Aaron Craven
Marko Lahma (.NET)

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.IBatchService.Start(System.String)
member.summary: Starts the already configured batch process with a given name.
member.param: The name of the batch process to be started.

remarks.para: The method starts a process with a given name. Such a process must already be used by the service or it must be returned by the current service factory.

When a service has been created with no explicit factory object it means it is using the list of batch processes defined in the application configuration file. In such a case the batch process requested must be configured in that file.
The batch process can be in the state. In such a case the process will be activated again and moved into the state. For more details about the process reactivation please look at the method.

member.exception: Thrown when a batch with a given name could not be found. The batch with a given name is expected to be managed by the or is expected to be returned by the currently configured batch process factory.

remarks.para: The method stops a process with a given name. Such a process must be already be used and started by the service or it must be returned by the current service factory.

When a service has been created with no explicit factory object it means it is using the list of batch processes defined in the application configuration file. In such a case the batch process requested must be configured in the app config.
The batch process can be in the state. In such a case the process will ignore the request.

para.code: ... <alias alias="IWindowsServiceBehaviour" type="Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Services.IWindowsServiceBehaviour, Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices" /> <alias alias="CustomService" type="WindowsServices.Sample.CustomService, WindowsServices.Sample" /> ... <container> ... <register type="IWindowsServiceBehaviour" mapTo="CustomService" name="WindowsServiceBase" /> ... </container> ... <![CDATA[

remarks.para: The above registers the CustomService as the windows service implementation. It registers it with the 'WindowsServiceBase' as the name. It is a default name used by the when a different one is not specified on the property (winServiceBaseImplementationName attribute).

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Services.NVSWinService
member.summary: The NVS windows service class simplifying creation, usage and management of windows services.

remarks.para: The class enables creation of windows services in a simplified way where a developer mainly focuses on the logic of the windows service itself with no need to focus on the service installation and service initialization.
Common tasks like service management, service operations (when run under the console application) are handled by the automatically.

For a simple creation of the NVS Windows Service one must provide the service implementation (the service logic). For this the class implementing the should be created. This is the FIRST step required to create your own service.

If you want to use standard (shared among various libraries and projects) logging capabilities you may derive from the class instead of the interface. The provides the property which can be used from your service logic class to log various information.

When your service should only react on Start and Stop commands and will not have a Pause and Resume functionality it is possible to derive from the class and implement the and the methods respectively. This is another simplification given over the base class. The still provides the basic logging capabilities of the .

Various NVS Libraries may provide out of the box implementations of the windows service behaviours, logic. For example provides the logic for the which is responsible for running scheduled batch processes (scheduler).
When a class holding the windows service logic is selected or created in order to provide project specific, custom windows service logic then the must be notified about this implementation.

The provides various constructors with multiple parameters where the name, description and the information about the windows service logic class can be provided. It all created the code-base configuration of the .

When a name of the windows service behaviour implementation is given (for example into the then a registration within the with that name is a must. The must be mapped into the selected or created windows service implementation class.
The information about the windows service implementation can also be provided directly by passing an instance of service behaviour object. See for example the where such an instance can bee given.

It is also possible to use the parameter-less constructor. In that case the configuration of the service is taken according to the performed fluent, common library configuration or from the current application configuration file when no fluent and global library configuration has been performed.

The must be mapped into the windows service implementation class within the when the application configuration file is used and no global code based configuration has been performed. The similar Unity configuration can be added in such a scenario:

para.code: ... <alias alias="IWindowsServiceBehaviour" type="Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Services.IWindowsServiceBehaviour, Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices" /> <alias alias="CustomService" type="WindowsServices.Sample.CustomService, WindowsServices.Sample" /> ... <container> ... <register type="IWindowsServiceBehaviour" mapTo="CustomService" name="WindowsServiceBase" /> ... </container> ... <![CDATA[

remarks.para: The above registration specifies the CustomService as the one providing implementation for the windows service logic. It is the CustomService which implements the directly or indirectly. The registration is added with the 'WindowsServiceBase' as the name. It is a default name used by the when no custom one is specified.

When the implementation is registered and the configuration in the application configuration file is used the must be configured as well. For this a similar configuration can be added into the application configuration file:

para.code: <configSections> ... <section name="volvo.nvs.winservice" type="Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Config.WinServiceSection, Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices" /> ... </configSections> ... <volvo.nvs.winservice> <service.info name="Service1" description="Sample Windows Service" winServiceBaseImplementationName="WindowsServiceBase" /> </volvo.nvs.winservice> ... <![CDATA[

remarks.para: The above configures the giving a name of the service and its description. The 'winServiceBaseImplementationName' attribute is also set into the 'WindowsServiceBase'. This attribute specifies the name of the registration to be taken from the Unity and matches an entry from the unity configuration file in the registration. In our sample it matches an entry for the CustomService which is providing a logic for the windows service.

The 'WindowsServiceBase' is a default name used even if the 'winServiceBaseImplementationName' would not be given. The name has been provided here in order to show usage of the winServiceBaseImplementationName attribute.
When the complete configuration of the NVS Windows Service basing on the application configuration file is done then the service can be run by usage of the static Run method:

Above code has initialized the service from the current application configuration file as no global, code-based library configuration had been performed. One may use global, common, library configuration in order to configure the from code and avoid any entries in the application configuration file.
The code based, common configuration is a short-cut to the constructors taking multiple parameters. The following is a sample executing the common, library code based configuration of the :

When the code-based, global service configuration is done a call to or usage of the parameter-less constructor will force usage of the configuration given in code. No application configuration file will be used in that case.
The installation of the service based on the can also be simplified and automated. See the class for details about installation.

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchWindowsService
member.summary: The NVS Windows Service logic running scheduled batch processes. The logic can be hosted by the .

remarks.para: The class enables simplified creation of Windows Services. When the is used the logic executed as the windows service logic should be provided by the implementation of the .

The provides windows service logic, windows service behaviour which is executing batch processes. The batch processes can be scheduled for execution according to the configuration placed in the application configuration file, fluent and code-based library configuration or by usage of one of the constructors taking batch process factory objects.

When the is used to create an instance of the batch windows service behaviour then the code-based and fluent library configuration is used or the current application configuration file is used to get batch process configuration.
The batches and the running the batches can be configured from code and by usage of the fluent, code-based and common library configuration object.

Once you have an instance of the common library configuration object you may use methods specific for the batch process configuration. The
extension method can be used.
The following sample code configures the to run the batch processes and specifies configuration of those batches:

The above configures two batch processes. One uses the interval time scheduler. The second is using the scheduler based on cron expressions. The batch handling objects (hanlder1, handler2) will be notified when scheduled events occur. They all implement the interface. The name and description is used as the windows service name and description.
The current application configuration file is used when no fluent, code-based configuration is provided and the parameter-less is used to create the instance of the batch windows service behaviour.

When one wants to use the current application configuration file then the first step required is to configure the itself. It is the which will use and manage the batch window service behaviour object. The following section can be provided in the app config file in order to configuration the :

According to the above we have the configuration section defined. The configuration of the windows service should point at the so the windows service will be used to run scheduled batch processes. The following can be specified for the service:
remarks.code: <service.info name="Batching" description="Sample Windows Service Running Batches" winServiceBaseImplementationName="BatchService" />
remarks.para: The name BatchService used on the service.info and on the winServiceBaseImplementationName attribute should be registered within the Unity and should point at the . The following can be added into the Unity configuration when the configuration file is used:

When above steps are completed the will run the batch scheduling logic as the windows service logic. The remaining step is to add batch processes to be run. The configuration of batch processes can also be added into the application configuration file. We start by defining a section for the batch process configuration:
The volvo.nvs.batch can then be defined and batches can be scheduled by usage of the interval attribute or schedule nodes holding cron expressions.

para.code: <volvo.nvs.batch> <batches> <add name="Every Five Seconds Batch" handler="FiveSecondsBatch" interval="00:00:05" waitForStop="00:00:10" start="true" /> <add name="Every 30 Seconds Batch" handler="ThritySecondsBatch" interval="00:00:30" waitForStop="00:00:10" start="true" /> <add name="Every Minute Batch" handler="EveryMinuteBatch" waitForStop="00:00:10" start="true"> <schedules> <add value="0 * * * * ?" /> </schedules> </add> </batches> </volvo.nvs.batch>

remarks.para: All the given batch handler names (handler attribute) such as FiveSecondsBatch, ThritySecondsBatch, EveryMinuteBatch must be registered within the Unity. The mapping should be for the type and into the implementation of the handler running the batch actions. The Unity mapping should be named as the handler itself. For example: the following can be added for EveryMinuteBatch into the Unity configuration file:
When the configuration is completed a call into the method will start the and the scheduled batch processes will run as configured in the application configuration file.

The batch can be scheduled for execution using an interval or a cron expression. An interval specifies the time between each batch run while the cron expression specifies exact point on the timeline at which the batches should execute. For more information check the and the classes.
Custom schedulers can be created. Check the base class and the interface.
The and the instances can be configured via the application configuration file. They can also be configured from code.
Custom schedulers can only be configured by usage of the code-based configuration.

para.para: The batches are started when the execution is initiated. Check the for details.

remarks.para: When a stop of the windows service is requested the will wait for batches to complete as defined on the waitForStop configuration attribute. The batch process is expected to complete in the given time and check the cancellation token passed into the method. When a batch is not stopped in the given time its state cannot be guaranteed. The executing batch can be aborted with all the consequences.

Wherever the batch windows service is stopping not only the waitForStop time matters when waiting for a stop. The operating system configuration has the higher priority and the Windows System may all the time decide to immediately abort execution of the process if stop operation is time consuming. All the stop limits are defined in the operating system registry for windows services and should not be modified from their default values.

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Services.StoppableWindowsService
member.summary: Provides basic implementation of a stoppable (start, stop) windows service together with logging capabilities.

remarks.para: The extends behaviours already added by the class and defines a base class for services which can be Started and Stopped. The services cannot be Paused and Resumed.

For a the ShutDown operation is the same as the Stop operation. For simpler usage the abstraction over Start and Stop of a service is provided. The and methods should be implemented by all the derived classes.
For details about logging functionality refer into the base class.

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Services.WindowsServiceBehaviour
member.summary: Provides basic implementation of the adding logging capabilities.

remarks.para: The class provides an easy and simplified way enabling us to create windows services. The resolves the implementation of the which itself provides a logic for the windows service.

The is a basic implementation of the . It gives the method which can be used by all other windows service implementations. This method logs into the if such one is active and with enabled stdin or writes using the when its implementation is available.
The implementation of the is resolved from the Unity Container. It is optional and when not given the logging functionality will be discarded.
All the derived classes may also access the resolved logger directly via the property. Even if the implementation of the is not available a not-null object is always available on the .

member.name: T:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Services.IWindowsServiceBehaviour
member.summary: Defines a contract for the windows service logic (behaviour) which is executed by the .

remarks.para: The implementation of the is resolved and used by the windows service class. This class helps in the windows service creation and execution.
When you want to easily create a windows service you just need to provide an implementation of the , register it within the Unity and use the .
Some windows service implementations are provided out of the box for example: the running batch processes according to the defined time schedules.
For more details check the class.

member.name: P:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Services.IWindowsServiceBehaviour.CanPauseAndContinue
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the service can be paused and resumed.

remarks.para: When a service cannot be paused and resumed the and the methods will never be called even if implemented.

When your service does the same actions on the OnPause event as on the OnStop even and the service does the same actions on the OnResume event as on the OnStart event then it means your service does not need to provide the pause and continue functionality as it would be exactly the same as start and stop. In that case the should return false.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchWindowsService.AddAndStart(Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.IScheduledBatchProcess)
member.summary: Adds a new scheduled batch process and queues it for execution.

remarks.para: The method adds a given batch process into the execution and running loop. The process will be run according to the configured scheduler on the process object itself. See .
The process name must be unique. It is not allowed to add a process with the same name more than once.
When a process is it will be reactivated and run.

member.param: The process to be added and to be queued for execution.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchWindowsService.Start(System.String)
member.summary: Starts the already configured batch process with a given name.
member.param: The name of the batch process to be started.

remarks.para: The method starts a process with a given name. Such a process must already be used by the service or it must be returned by the current service factory.

When a service has been created with no explicit factory object it means it is using the list of batch processes defined in the application configuration file. In such a case the batch process requested must be configured in the app config.
The batch process can be in the state. In such a case the process will be activated and moved into the state. For more details about the process reactivation please look at the method.

member.exception: Thrown when a batch with a given name could not be found. The batch with a given name is expected to be managed by the or is expected to be returned by the currently configured batch process factory.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchWindowsService.RequestRunnerStop
member.summary: Requests stop of the main scheduling loop sending a cancellation signal.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchWindowsService.Stop(System.String)
member.summary: Stops the already configured and running batch process with a given name.
member.param: The name of the batch process to be started.

remarks.para: The method stops a process with a given name. Such a process must be already be used and started by the service or it must be returned by the current service factory.

When a service has been created with no explicit factory object it means it is using the list of batch processes defined in the application configuration file. In such a case the batch process requested must be configured in the app config.
The batch process can be in the state. In such a case the process will ignore the request.

member.exception: Thrown when a batch with a given name could not be found. The batch with a given name is expected to be managed by the or is expected to be returned by the currently configured batch process factory.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchWindowsService.WaitForRunnerStop
member.summary: Waits for the main scheduling loop to stop.
member.remarks: This method can be used when a stop is requested by .
member.returns: True if stopped otherwise false.

member.name: M:Volvo.NVS.Utilities.WindowsServices.Batch.BatchWindowsService.Stop
member.summary: Stops the service and waits for the batch processes to be completed as defined on the stop timeout.
member.returns: True if the service has been stopped and all batch processes has completed. False if the service has been stopped but not all batch processes were completed on time.
